x 1919 Gunnar von Wright

° 3.7.1894 Hanko + 3.5.1975

Son of Ferdinand von Wright et Johanna Maria Nykopp.

He was Finnish Jaeger Colonel. Gunnar von Wright graduated from the Helsinki New Swedish secondary school in 1913 and joined the Uusimaa Students’ Association. He continued his studies at Helsinki University mechanical engineer Department from 1913 to 1915. He visited the General Department War College in 1925-1926. Gunnar von Wright joined as a volunteer in Germany to provide military training Jaeger Battalion 27’s. He took part in battles in the First World War on the Eastern Front German Misse River, the Gulf of Riga and the River Aa. After Rintamakomennuksensa he went to Libau in 1917, the school held a war-B course.

Gunnar von Wright arrived in Finland with the main body of infantrymen, being raised to lieutenant on 25 February 1918. He was ordered to the Finnish Civil War Adjutantti 3. Jaeger 7. He took part in the Civil War battles in Tampere, Aitto Gulf, Lyykylässä, Mannikkalassa and Tali, where he was wounded in battle on 24 April 1918.

Gunnar von Wright was transferred at the end of the civil war 24 May 1918 to General Headquarters in the cab, which he passed on in June the same year General Staff organization department. Within departments, he was transferred on November 1, 1918 the Ministry of War War general affairs department, and continues to December 19, 1918 of the General Staff mobilization department. Head of the mobilization department, he was appointed on 3 March 1920. The Ministry of Defence curator of the department, he was transferred on 13 July 1926.

Gunnar von Wright participated in the Winter War liaison officer from the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of People’s Service. Continuation War broke out he was transferred to Headquarters, where he served as liaison officer Military, Financial Manager and Public Service of the Ministry between. After the war, he became managing director of First Industrial Fuel Oil Ltd, and later Western Finland Fuel Oil Ltd. Gunnar von Wright worked as assistant to the Swedish Military Academy teachers and general staff service military history education, 25 November 1925 – July 31, 1926 during the period.

Gunnar von Wright served as chairman, member and secretary of defense now several arrangements and the development of the kingdom of defense capabilities in dealing with the economic committees of the years 1922-1928. He was also examining board set against carried out in the Swedish language qualifications assessors in 1928-1935 and central military committee member for the years 1928-1933. a member of the General Staff Honorary Court and served from 1922, from 1924 to 1925 and honorary member of the Council of Deputy years 1922-1923.

1.1.4.1.1.(b).2.11.1.6.(a).3.4.1. Göran Casimir Ehrnrooth

° 6.4.1931 Helsinki + 8.7.2015 from a sudden cardiac arrest at his home in Mallorca

He was a Finnish magnate and former chairman of the Nokia Corporation. His business career began in the forest industry, and later he was a director of UPM-Kymmene and Merita-Nordbanken. Ehrnrooth inherited substantial holdings in important companies from both his paternal and maternal families. His paternal family were in banking, while his maternal forefathers were founders of Fiskars and Kaukas industries. His earlier family tree includes notable military men. He had a degree in law from Helsinki University.

Casimir Ehrnrooth succeeded his maternal relatives as President and CEO of Kaukas paper factory and he served there for long. Ehrnrooth also owned Vanantaka manor in Janakkala [illustration ci-dessous].

° 1954

Ehrnrooth joined Pöyry in 1979 as an Economist in the Project Economics Department. During 1981-85 he was managing several research and development projects. In 1985 Mr. Ehrnrooth became partner and co-owner of Jaakko Pöyry Oy and was appointed President and CEO of the company in 1986. In 1995 he was appointed Chief Executive Officer of Pöyry. Since 1997 he has been member of the Board of Directors of Pöyry PLC and in 1997-2002 he was Vice Chairman of the Board. Since 2003 Ehrnrooth has been the Chairman of the Board of Directors.

She was nominated for the Ars Fennica award in 2001, and her works are found in many private collections and in all of Finland’s major public collections, including the Amos Anderson Art Museum, the Helsinki Museum of Contemporary Art Kiasma and the Saastamoinen Foundation Art Collection.

He was the company’s president from 1969-1983 and Executive Chairman during the 1984-2006 period. Ehrnrooth as Vice President during the company wound down its traditional steel production and focused on the 1980s, the production of consumer goods. Ehrnrooth has also participated in a number of Finnish companies in the work of the government from the late 1960s onwards. Ehrnrooth has been affected in the 1970s and 1980s, the industry’s interest groups such as the Industrial Federation of the Board of Directors and the Finnish Confederation of the Representative Council.

1.1.4.1.1.(b).2.11.1.6.(a).3.4.2.2. Albert Ehrnrooth

° 1976

New generation takes over Kiala farm : Albert Ehrnrooth take over the farm. Kiala is one of the largest farms in the country with around 400 hectares of cultivated land. Today driven Kiala farm livestock loose and cereals, canola and hay are the main crops. Kiala yard has a history that stretches back to the 1400s. Carl Johan Adlercreutz (° 1757), who was an officer during the war of 1808-09, built the current character of the building at Kiala 1796.

« Until 1998, it was my father and my uncle, Göran J. Ehrnrooth and Robert G. who owned the farm, says Albert Ehrnrooth. This year I took my brother Alexander of my uncle’s part, and now we did a generation which means that I take over Kiala farm ».

In April officially transferred ownership to him. There are a couple of years since the family began to think about this generational change, and now felt that the time was right.

Albert Ehrnrooth is not itself a practical farmer. He is an economist and has worked with others. The last five years he has had a lot of responsibility for the farm business, he says.

1.1.4.1.1.(b).2.11.1.6.(a).4. Axel Reinhold Ehrnrooth

° 25.10.1867 Helsingfors + 4.1.1950 Helsingfors

He was a Finnish businessman and a bank manager who served as Chief Executive Officer Privatbanken.

He took his matriculation examination in Helsinki yksityislyseosta 1887, made a study trip to England in 1888 and studied law at the University of Helsinki.

Ehrnrooth work of the Union Bank clerk and the clerk 1889-1891, Tornator office manager 1892-1893, and the People’s Bank Ltd’s director from 1893 to 1896. He was Privatbanken Director 1896-1904 and Chief Executive Officer from 1904 to 1922. Privatbanken took the outbreak of the First World War at the time of 10 million Swedish kronor loan to the terms of which the loan was paid back in a period of time after the end of the war.

During the war, the Finnish markka traded against the Swedish krona weakened due to inflation, so that the loan amount in marks rose in 1914 from 15 million marks to 1921 by about 140 million marks. The bank’s position became more difficult, therefore, so that it eventually was merged in January 1922 the Nordic Union Bank. Bank depositors were rescued but the shareholders lost their investments. He was also chairman and honorary member of the Helsinki stock exchange club. Ehrnrooth took part in the Diet a representative of the nobility.

x 5.12.1896 Carl-Erik Mannerheim

° 17.3.1865 Villnäs + 6.7.1915 Stockholm

Son of Carl Robert Mannerheim & Hedvig Charlotta Helena von Julin. The paternal line of the Mannerheim family had come to Sweden from the Netherlands in the 17th century and had great influence on the conditions in Finland during the first decades of autonomy. At Gustaf’s birth, the family was one of the best-known noble families in the country. Mannerheim’s father, Carl Robert, Count Mannerheim (1835–1914), was a playwright who held liberal and radical political ideas, but he was also an industrialist whose success varied.

Lillemor Mannheimer was educated at the Higher School of Art and Design in Stockholm in the years 1945-1949 and the Académie de la Grande Chaumiere, Paris, the years 1950-1952.

She worked as an artist at Gefle Porcelain and Rörstrand porcelain factory. She was also active as a designer at the glassworks and Arabia porcelain factory. Lillemor Mannerheim designed the animal figures, furniture, vases and bowls. Hyacinth and sunflower, both for Gävle Porslinsfabrik are examples of two tea services that she designed. Lillemor Mannerheim participated in exhibitions at the Triennale in Milan in 1954, Gävle Museum in 1955 and Presenta in Uppsala in 1956.

° 1962

Holder of the estate Hellekis manor [illustration ci-dessous]. The manor is known since the 14th century. The present manor-house in late Gustavian style was designed by the architect Olof Tempelman. The main building, as well as the stables, has kept their original character from the 1790’s. The manor is owned and lived in by the Klingspor family since 1915.

The park of the manor is famous for its many beautiful trees, e.g. walnut tree and chestnut. These trees are very rare at our degree of latitude. Also, the magnificient perennial flower beds are a source of inspiration and knowledge for visiting garden enthusiasts. In the park there is also a rosarium with old garden roses. The main building is private, however, a part of the beautiful park is open to the public during the summer season.

° 7.12.1898 Helsinki + 16.9.1983

He was a Finnish cavalry Major General who served in the war Häme cavalry regiment commander and later regional administrations, in particular the military commander. Gustaf Ehrnrooth was also the head of the honor guard at the funeral of Marshal Mannerheim. The 1952 Helsinki Olympics, he was the director responsible for riding competitions.

Promotions : Cornet in 1920, lieutenant in 1920, Cavalry Captain in 1924, Major in 1928, Lieutenant-Colonel in 1938, Colonel in 1941, Major-General in 1955.

Ehrnrooth work in the 1920s Cavalry Brigade and Uusimaa cavalry regiment, inter alia, the younger officer and eskadroonanpäällikön positions. Between 1930-1938, he served as an officer in the ye-Cavalry Brigade and the Uusimaa Dragoon Regiment. Between 28.12.1938-12.10.1939 he was 2. Division Chief of Staff.

After the war, he was commander of the military district of Porvoo 1944-1950. Until 1955, he worked at the Helsinki Military District Manager. Uusimaa provincial military commander and garrison manager in Helsinki, he worked since 1955 at all times until his retirement in 1958.

1.1.4.1.1.(b).2.11.1.6.(a).6.(a).5. Adolf Erik Ehrnrooth

° 9.2.1905 Helsinki + 26.2.2004 Turku buried in Hietaniemi cemetery – Helsinki

He was a Finnish general who served during the Winter and Continuation wars. Ehrnrooth entered cadet school in 1922 and served in the Uusimaa Dragoon Regiment. During the brief Winter War against the Soviet Union, he served on the staffs of the 7th Division and the Cavalry Brigade. When the Continuation War, also against the Soviet Union, broke out in June 1941, he served as the chief of staff of the 2nd Division until he was seriously wounded. After he recovered he was appointed to lead the 7th Infantry regiment of the 2nd Division.

During the battles on the Karelian Isthmus, he was awarded the Mannerheim cross. After the war, he led an active military career until he retired in 1965.

Adolf Ehrnrooth was the face and voice most associated with rehabilitation of the soldiers who secured Finland her independence. The long post-war era during which it simply was not progressive to value the military ended in the early 1990s, at which time his charismatic persona was at its height.

He became a figurehead for the whole veteran community-straight-talking and unapologetic. He was voted as the 4th greatest Finn of all time by the Finnish public during the Suuret suomalaiset (Great Finns) competition in 2004.

x 4.12.1792 Loviisa Carl Johan Count Adlercreutz [armoiries]

° 27.4.1757 Borgå (Finland) + 21.8.1815 Stockholm

Was a Swedish general and statesman. Entering the Swedish army aged 13 in the Finnish Light Cavalry Brigade, he was present when Gustav III launched his coup-d’etat. He studied military theory in Stockholm. In 1777 he joined the Savolax Brigade protecting the Finnish border against Russian aggression. Adlercreutz first saw action in the 1788-1790 Russo-Swedish War, where he distinguished himself. He was promoted Major in 1791 and Squadron Commander 1792. During the Anjala mutiny he remained faithful to the King, standing against the war with Russia, then took part in the trials against the conspirators. He was thereafter appointed the commanding officer of the Nyland Dragoons, holding this post until 1804, when he was made Colonel-in-Chief of the newly raised Adlercreutz Regiment.

At the opening of the Finnish war Adlercreutz was appointed Ofverste commanding the 2nd brigade under Klercker. He replaced Gustaf Löwenhielm as Wilhelm Mauritz Klingspor’s Chief of Staff on 14 April. Adlercreutz distinguished himself in action at Siikajoki, 18 April, and at Revolax, 27th. On 24 June he forced the Russians from Nykarleby. As CO of the Northern ‘Army’ he drove Raevsky from Lappo in a brilliant action on 14 July, then defeated the Russians again at Alavo in August. At the end of that month he was appointed to command the ‘Finnish’ Division under Klingspor. Forced to retreat due to the Swedish victories not being exploited, he was severely defeated by Nikolay Kamensky at the Battle of Oravais 14 September, which obliged him to abandon Finland.

Adlercreutz returned to Stockholm to take charge of a military junta ruling the country in place of the insane King Gustav IV after the Coup of 1809. With Georg Adlersparre, on 13 March 1809 at the head of the Junta he arrested the King and seized power. Adlercreutz proposed that he himself should be made king, but the French General Bernadotte was chosen instead as Crown Prince Charles XIII. Later the two generals quarreled, and Adlersparre was disgraced, while Adlercreutz remained in favor, elected Count and took a seat in the Government.

In 1813 Adlercreutz was made General and appointed Chief of Staff to Curt von Stedingk under the Crown Prince’s Swedish Army of the North in Germany 1813. He served at the Battle of Leipzig 16–19 October, and was made a Commander of the Austrian Order of Maria Theresa, 88/144 promotion 1813-14. (x (b) 1798 Margareta von Engeström, daughter of bergsrådet Gustaf von Engeström and Abela Charlotta Lagerbring. He was the father of Fredrik Adlercreutz and uncle of Axel Gustav Adlercreutz).

1.1.4.1.1.(b).3.2.1. Fredrik Tomas Baron Adlercreutz

° 25.8.1793 Gammelbacka in Porvoo (Finland) + 9.11.1852 Stockholm

Baron together with his father in 1808, Count when his father died in 1815. Cornet at the Life Regiment kyrassiärkår 1809. He grew up on the estates Gammelbacka and Kiala in Finland, and was written in 1806 as a cadet at the Karlberg military school, where he graduated in 1809 officer. Adlercreutz unescorted 1810 the Swedish throne (Karl XIV Johan) to Stockholm and won his trust. In the following years, he served as a royal courier and messenger and 1813-14 as the crown prince’s personal adjutant at the allied Northern Army Staff. Adlercreutz stood out among others in the Battle of Breitenfeld October 7, 1813, where his father commanded. He also participated in the Norwegian campaign in 1814.

After garrison duty in Stockholm went Adlercreutz to South America, where he in 1820 became the Republic of Colombia Service and tied friendships with Simon Bolivar. He made an important contribution at intake of Cartagena in 1821 and included the following year marriage to a Spanish officer daughter. Adlercreutz was appointed in 1828 by Bolivar to the provincial governor, but after his death in 1830 he was expelled and could return to South America first nine years later, now as Swedish Consul General in Venezuela. From this service he received farewell 1852nd

« You really see, the last image, how he is supposed to have been : constantly angry. Moreover, he was almost stone deaf (it was because he was angry ?). Or was it to life tested him hard ?

« He was separated from parents and siblings, except one older brother. The brother died a few years after they came to Tosterup in Skåne. Carlos became the father of three children with his wife Luitgard Colliander. She died when the third child, Luitgard was born. After Carlos remarried, he became father for a fourth time. The girl, Zoila, died when she was only 4-5 years.

One of the daughters, Eleanor, was not like the others, but he managed to get her married off. The marriage lasted only a few years, then threw the man out « Nuttan » with the words « I can not stand another day. »

The same year, a few months later, the scandal occurred : the second son in law escaped with a circus princess, killed herself and her daughter, and left Carlos luck remain as 30-year-old widow. Of all the difficulties experienced Carlos must be the year 1889 has been his « annus horribilis ». His obituary was : constantly furious. Was it encapsulated sadness that made Carlos furious ? Poor Granny Grandpa ! »

1.1.4.1.1.(b).3.2.1.3.(a).1.2. Axel Fredrik Carlos Adlercreutz

° 26.1.1890 Stockholm + 7.10.1963 Enköping

Was a Swedish Army officer. Adlercreutz is credited with the formation of the General Security Service in 1938, and the intelligence agency C-byrån in 1939. He became passed studentexamen in 1908 and became a Second lieutenant at the Svea Life Guards in 1910 and received a Candidate of Law degree in Stockholm in 1916. Adlercreutz attended the Royal Swedish Army Staff College from 1918 to 1920, the French War College from 1920 to 1922 and did a course at the French Air Force in 1922. He was promoted to Captain in 1925 and served at the General Staff in 1926. Adlercreutz was expert assistance of Sweden’s representative at the League of Nations’ disarmament commission from 1929 to 1931 and then served as military attaché in Helsinki from 1932 to 1935.

He was Major at the General Staff in 1933 and served at Älvsborg Regiment in 1935 and was promoted to Lieutenant Colonel in 1936. Adlercreutz was head of the International Department of the General Staff in 1936 and then the Intelligence Department of the Defence Staff from 1937 to 1942. Adlercreutz was promoted to colonel in 1939 and served again as military attaché in Helsinki from 1942 to 1945. He was back serving at the Defence Staff in 1945, the same year he retired from active service. Adlercreutz remained in the General Staff Corps Reserve until 1960.

Adlercreutz became a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of War Sciences in 1944. He wrote essays in journals and was editor of « Arméer, flottor och flyg from » 1938 to 1941. After his retirement he ran Brunnsholms Manor [illustration ci-dessous] in Enköping.

x 29.9.1880 Kristianstad Bengt Edvard Sixten Sparre af Rossvik

° 27.9.1854 Malmö + 20.7.1889 Troense (Denmark)

Also known as « Sixten Sparre » ; son of Gabriel Gerhard Sparre af Rossvik & Adelaide Virginia Peijron ; Lieutenant at the Royal Skåne Dragoon Regiment in Kristianstad.

Mort par suicide à Nørreskov, sur l’île danoise de Tåsinge, fut un lieutenant d’un régiment suédois de dragons, connu essentiellement pour la liaison secrète et à l’issue fatale qu’il entretint avec la funambule danoise Elvira Madigan.

En 1873, il s’enrôla dans le régiment de dragons de Scanie, caserné à Kristianstad. Il passa son examen de maturité en 1875, intégra le corps des officiers en 1876 et fut promu au grade de lieutenant de seconde classe en 1887. Le 29 septembre 1880, il épousa Luitgard Engel Agda Dorotea Adlercreutz. Ils eurent deux enfants, une fille et un garçon, mais formèrent un couple sans affection.

Assistant en 1888 à une représentation de cirque à Kristianstad, il s’éprit de la belle-fille du directeur, la danseuse funambule Elvira Madigan (1867-1889). Ils nouèrent une liaison romantique, qui se poursuivit par des échanges de lettres lorsque le cirque quitta la ville. En juin 1889, Sixten Sparre ayant retrouvé Elivra Madigan, qui avait fui sa famille, il gagna Stockholm, puis, via Copenhague, la ville danoise de Svendborg, où ils séjournèrent à l’hôtel en se faisant passer pour un couple en lune de miel. Bientôt, cependant, ils se trouvèrent à bout de ressources. Sans argent ni espoir, ils décidèrent d’en finir. Le 20 juillet 1889, ils partirent pour une promenade dans les bois de l’île de Tåsinge. Sixten avait emmené avec lui son revolver de service, avec lequel peut être il abattit Elvira Madigan puis se suicida.

Sixten Sparre est enterré avec Elvira Madigan dans le cimetière de l’église Saint-Georges de Landet [illustration ci-dessus]. Une pierre de granit commémorative a également été installée sur les lieux où leurs corps ont été découverts, dans le bois de Nørreskov.

Mozart – Concerto Piano – Elvira Madigan

À la date du 11 juillet 1889, Sixten avait noté dans son journal : « À mon ami John Rothstein, de la part de Sixten, qui est parti le premier : il n’y a personne pour te faire du bien sans contrepartie. On ne rencontre que des usuriers de la pire espèce. Ainsi va la vie, de A à Z. Quand l’homme naît, on se réjouit ; quand il meurt, on pleure. Ce devrait être l’inverse. »

° 8.7.1866 Östergötland + 27.9.1955

Was a Swedish officer and horse rider who competed in the 1912 Summer Olympics. He and his horse Atout finished fourth in the individual eventing competition and won a gold medal with the Swedish team. He also finished sixth in the individual jumping with another horse Ilex.

Already in 1887, the year before he graduated high school in Norrköping, Adlercreutz had been a volunteer at the Life Guards on horseback. After graduating from the Military School in 1890 he became a second lieutenant in the regiment but was transferred the following year to the riding school at Strömsholm where he was after the passing equerry rate from 1891 to 1893 became a lieutenant in 1896. The years 1897 to 1899, he underwent War College and then became ordonnansofficer at IV. Army distribution’s team, as he was in 1902. He returned for service abroad (see below) to Stromsholm, now teaching there from 1906 to 1908. Last year he was both captain as head of the officers’ and reservist volunteering school in the cavalry in Umeå, as he was in 1909. He became a major in the Scanian Dragoon Regiment in 1914 and lieutenant colonel there in 1917. In 1918 he became a colonel and head of the Småland Hussar regiment but returned in 1921 to Scanian Dragoon regiment as its director, a role he remained in until his retirement in 1927.

Adlercreutz 1902-1903 had been commanded to serve at the 2nd Pomeranian ulanregementet No. 9 in Germany and returned to this country from 1912 to 1918 as a military attache at the Swedish Embassy in Berlin. As such, he also spent during the First World War when the German military headquarters as well as at the German sydarmén spring of 1915 and the Bavarian Cavalry Division in 1916. He then participated in the offensives in Serbia, Galicia, Romania, Italy and the Western Front. He served as secretary and of Stockholm Riding Club and a judge at riding competitions. His son Gregor also became an Olympic equestrian.

° 25.9.1878 Stockholm + 17.3.1968

Swedish Army general and sports shooter. Cederschiöld was the son of the Director-General of Swedish Customs Staffan Cederschiöld and Sophie (née Montgomery Cederhielm). He became a second lieutenant at Svea Life Guards in 1898 and was promoted to lieutenant in 1903 when he was commanded to serve the Duke of Skåne. The year after Cederschiöld was an orderly officer to the Duke of Skåne.He attended the Royal Swedish Army Staff College from 1906 to 1908 and served as regimental adjutant in 1908. Cederschiöld was 1st adjutant at the staff of the IV. Army Division from 1911 to 1915. He as promoted to captain in 1912 and served as adjutant to the Crown Prince the same year. Cederschiöld served as brigade quartermaster at the 7th infantry brigrade from 1917 to 1922. He was promoted to lieutenant colonel in 1926 and was the head of Infantry Combat School from 1926 to 1931. In 1930, Cederschiöld was promoted to colonel and was the chief of staff of the Crown Prince the same year. He was commander of Life Regiment Grenadiers from 1931 to 1936 and ccommander of Svea Life Guards from 1936 to 1938.

Cederschiöld was expert and secretary of the Shooting Instruction Committee in 1918. He was teacher at the Infantry Combat School (Infanteriets stridsskola) from 1919 to 1923, expert and secretary in the Drill Regulations Committee from 1921 to 1922 and was promoted to major in 1921 before serving at Svea Life Guards in 1922.

Cederschiöld was promoted to major general in 1937 and was commendant of Stockholm from 1938 to 1945, as well as defense area commander from 1942 to 1945 and acting inspector of the infantry in 1940. He was promoted to lieutenant general and placed in the reserve in 1950. The same year, Cederschiöld became chief of staff to His Hajesty the King, a position he stayed in until 1963.

Cederschiöld was a member of numerous committees and was active in the Voluntary Shooting Movement (Frivilliga skytterörelsen) and the Landstormen. He became a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of War Sciences in 1929. Cederschiöld was also president of the Swedish-English Association from 1939 to 1955 and president of Stockholm’s Rotary Club from 1940 to 1941 and governor of Sweden’s Rotary District number 78A from 1948 to 1950. Cederschiöld was also member of the European Rotary International Council from 1948 and was chairmna of numerous associations.

Count of Mühlhausen, Gondelsheim, Skenninge and Stjernorp, Lord of Langenstein and Stjernorp castles, was a conservative Swedish politician and official. He was a direct patrilineal descendant of Field Marshal Robert Douglas. His parents were Count Carl Israel Douglas, first count of the Douglas family in the nobility of Baden (since 1848) as Count of Mühlhausen, and his wife countess Louise von Gondelsheim and Langenstein, herself a daughter of the morganatic marriage of Louis I, Grand Duke of Baden and Katharina Werner. Through his mother, he was a second cousin of Victoria of Baden, wife of King Gustaf V of Sweden.

He received the fideicommiss of Muhlhausen and the castle of Langenstein as his share of the family inheritance and reclaimed in 1875 his ancestral castle of Stjernorp in Sweden, which had been lost to his family after a fire in 1789. He ultimately succeeded his childless elder brother as head of the comital House of Douglas.

Douglas was a protectionist and solidly oriented towards Germany. From 1895 to 1899, he served as Minister of Foreign Affairs of Sweden. He resigned because he refused to accept that Norway (then in union with Sweden) would have their flag without the mark of the union, i.e. he opposed the so-called pure flag.

He also held the position of Riksmarskalk (Marshal of the Realm) (1911-1916), Landshövding (governor) of Uppsala County (1893-1895), and Landshövding (governor) of Östergötland County (1901-1912). Douglas worked for the Norrlander farmers’ party against the forest products companies, they demanded protective legislation in field of wood market.

1.1.4.1.1.(b).3.2.2.1.2.1.4. Anna Eva Elisabeth Baroness Adelswärd

° 2.2.1906 Stockholm + 21.12.1993 Stockholm

Also known as « Anna Sparre ». Auteur de plusieurs romans historiques importants, elle passa sa jeunesse tant en province, au manoir familial d’Adelsnäs, [illustration ci-dessous] que dans la capitale suédoise, aussi longtemps que son père fut membre du Parlement, et plus tard ministre des Finances du second gouverne-ment de Karl Staaf.

En 1927, elle se marie avec le comte Clas Sparre, un ingénieur aviateur de huit ans son aîné, fils de l’artiste peintre Louis comte Sparre dont les ancêtres remontent jusqu’au XIIIè siècle. Clas Sparre, bel homme, était de nature charmante, mais têtu. De leur union naquit Christina qui bientôt allait devenir une camarade de jeu pour Joséphine-Charlotte : les deux enfants étaient à peu près du même âge. Cela explique pourquoi, au cours de l’histoire que nous raconte Sparre, les deux jeunes mamans comparèrent plus d’une fois leurs bambins : leur première dent, les premiers pas, leur premier balbutiement …

La Deuxième Guerre mondiale éclate en 1939. La Suède, neutre, est isolée au milieu des belligérants, ce qui nécessitera une mobilisation permanente pendant près de six ans et des mesures restrictives d’approvisionnement. Anna Sparre s’engage dans les forces armées auxiliaires féminines et y devient chef de propagande. Se remariant après la guerre avec un dentiste danois, Stig Klingspor [photo ci-contre], elle vécut huit ans au Danemark. Mais ce mariage chavira, tout comme le premier. La comtesse avouait d’ailleurs ne pas être facile à vivre, assoiffée, comme elle se plaisait à le répéter, de la liberté. Après ses échecs conjugaux et pour subvenir à ses besoins, elle transforma le manoir familial en hôtel pour golfeurs. A la suite d’une rupture de ligaments dans les années septante, Anna Sparre fut astreinte à une vie plus sédentaire.

C’est à ce moment que débute vraiment sa carrière de romancière. En 1970 parut son premier roman, le premier d’une longue série de deux douzaines publiés à la cadence d’un par an. A l’exception de quelques chroniques familiales, Anna Sparre a écrit pulsieurs romans historiques, l’instar de sa mère, avec pratiquement toujours des femmes comme héroïnes, le plus souvent des têtes couronnées ou des dames issues de la noblesse.

On retiendra particulièrement « Astrid, mon amie » , un livre qui est tout d’abord l’histoire d’une indéfectible amitié. A six ans, la princesse Astrid, troisième fille du prince Carl de Suède et future reine des Belges, rencontre Anna Sparre. Au fil du temps, des liens d’une profonde amitié se tisseront entre les deux jeunes filles. En 1985, cinquante ans après la mort tragique d’Astrid à Küssnacht, Anna Sparre publie le récit de cette amitié.

Grâce à elle, nous voyons grandir et s’épanouir Astrid, nous la voyons aller à la rencontre de son destin et rejoindre l’histoire de la Belgique de l’entre-deux-guerres. Si la jeune Astrid était la douceur même, d’une extrême sensibilité et d’une grande timidité, Anna avait le verbe moqueur, elle était délurée, espiègle, on ne peut plus extravertie.

Gosta Adelswärd is one Östergötland cultural personality which meant a lot of at-wide mountain culture. He grew up on the villa in Atvidaberg and he became after his studies in Uppsala their home faithful. He was what you might call a private scholar. His academic training was a lawyer, but his formation humanist. « To cultivate his garden » was for him really a philosophy of life – with it was not just his garden in Atvidaberg which he, in the literal sense, cultivated with great success. He also cultivated scholars and amusing knowledge of different cultural topics, which he then processed and passed on to the listeners and readers.

His lessons might seem easy-going, but the entertaining arguments bottomed always idjup knowledge. His large and wide production is difficult to grasp because he mainly published in article form. The articles found in newspapers, magazines or yearbooks today are difficult to obtain. But with this bibliography facilitated the work of searching for his writings.

Fr Nicolas von Malaise Ordination & First Mass :

« On Saturday 19th January 2013 at St Georges Cathedral, Southwark, Deacon Nicolas von Malaisé was ordained priest by Archbishop Peter Smith. Father Nicolas started his ministry as an Anglican priest, his last parish was in Birmingham, and Saturday was the beginning of a new chapter in his life. Seven years ago as an Anglican priest he married Kirsty and they have a son, Matthias. After he was received into the Catholic Church he embarked on a course of formation at St John’s seminary in preparation for ordination to the Catholic diaconate and priesthood.

On Sunday 20th January at Our Lady Immaculate Parish he celebrated his “first” Mass. Afterwards he gave his first blessing and joined many of the parishioners for refreshments and the cutting of a cake made especially for the occasion. Fr. Nicolas will work at Our Lady Immaculate parish as an assistant priest until he is appointed as a parish priest later in the year.

Some Catholics ask, “How can a former Anglican be ordained a Catholic priest as he is married ?” A married former Anglican minister can be ordained as a Catholic deacon and then priest, because he is exempt by a special favour or dispensation from the Holy Father of making the promise of celibacy ; however, if he later became a widower, then he would be bound to a celibate lifestyle and could not remarry.

x 2005 Kirsty Staines

° 1974

Kirsty was educated at the Purcell School of Music and was a scholar at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, before reading English at Christ’s College, Cambridge. She was Head of English at two London state schools before moving into the independent sector. Prior to her Headship at Norwich High School, she was Deputy Head at Putney High School.

Kirsty is a strong advocate of girls’ only education, having worked predominantly in this sector developing strategies for raising girls’ aspirations and equipping them to achieve them. She is delighted to be the Headmistress of Norwich High School, which has such a strong and long track record of developing confident and successful young women.
